userestrict.p: All researchers seeking to publish materials from the collections of the John Hay Library are requested to complete a Notice of Intent to Publish, prior to reproducing, quoting, or otherwise publishing any portion or extract from this collection. Although Brown University has physical ownership of the collection and the materials contained therein, it does not claim literary rights. It is up to the researcher to determine the owners of the literary rights and to obtain any necessary permissions from them.

accessrestrict.p: There are no restrictions on access, except that the collection can only be seen by prior appointment. Some materials may be stored off-site and cannot be produced on the same day on which they are requested.

did.unittitle: Ferdinand de LessepsNew York, NY

scopecontent.p: Newspaper clipping from a New York newspaper about Ferdinand de Lesseps, presumably published shortly after he died on December 7, 1894. The article underscores the corruption surrounding De Lesseps's project to construct the Panama Canal, which—the author asserts—overshadowed the man's earlier career achievements.

did.unittitle: The Talk of ParisNew York, NY

scopecontent.p: Newspaper clipping of an article published in the New York Evening Post on December 26, 1894 but written in Paris on December 14, signed with the initials "S.D." Column dedicated to several recent illustrious deaths currently being discussed in Paris. Most of the article is given to Ferdinand de Lesseps, recounting to his rise in the French foreign service, efforts to construct the Suez Canal, and his impressive physical stature as the well-known "grand Français." The article's final paragraphs also mention the deaths of Jean Macé and M. Burdeau. Macé was a long-time Republican Senator in France dedicated to the principles of liberalism and a popular writer of science books, most famously his History of a Mouthful of Bread. Burdeau was at one time the deputy of the French Chamber of Deputies. Attention is given to both Macé's and Burdeau's resistance to Socialism.

did.unittitle: Conseil Général and Coup d'ÉtatMarseille and Paris, France

scopecontent.p: Several documents from French political meetings in 1849 and 1851. Contains first a program from the November 12, 1849 election for the position of conseil d'ètat, which lists the seven candidates: Colladon, Eugène; Cramer, ancien Syndic; Dufour, Général; Jacquier, Maire; Macaire-Prinsep; Montfalcon, Maire; and Odier-Cazenove. Also includes voting cards labelled "Oui" and "Non" from the vote held in Marseille on December 21, 1851 on whether or not to execute a coup d'état. An entrance ticket from a meeting of the National Assembly contains a hand-written note on the back stating that it was issued just one week before the 1851 coup d'état. These documents are all held together in an envelope containing a handwritten note about the Marseille vote.

did.unittitle: The Republican Alliance
did.container: 2-16, plus one page tucked between pages 2 and 3

scopecontent.p: Handwritten copy of Giuseppe (here anglicized to "Joseph") Mazzini's "Republican Alliance," as read in an article published in the Atlantic Monthly in February 1867 and reprinted on January 16, 1867 in the New York Tribune. (Copy not in Mazzini's hand, but appears to be a study copy and includes underlining and capitalization of significant passages.) Tribune clipping is tucked between scrapbook pages. Mazzini writes on the occasion of the "peace now concluded" in the war for Italian unification, arguing that as long as Italy remains a monarchy, it is not fully independent of foreign rule. Only a republican national government can achieve the true liberation of a united Italian people.

did.unittitle: Bulewski's ProposalWashington, DC

scopecontent.p: Louis Bulewski, the envoy of the European Republican Committee to America, proposes a three-part plan to garner American support for European revolutionary efforts, after having spoken with members of the Friends of Republican Principles in America. did.unittitle: Bulewski, Louis to SirLondon, England

scopecontent.p: Apologizies, presumably to Rush Hawkins, for the delay in an answer from the European Republican Committee about forming a "practical cooperative" with its American counterpart, but notes that before responding, the European committee wanted to see whether or not the current war in Europe between Bismark, Napoleon III, the Emperor of Russia, and "humiliated Italy" would "furnish a new yoke to the peoples of Europe." Proceeds with a lengthy overview of European political affairs and criticizes the military aggression of Prussia. Expresses the hope that at the very least, recent events would provide a fertile opportunity for Republican propaganda. Concludes with a firm call to the Friends of Republican Principles in America,, inviting them to prove whether or not they are "men of deeds."

did.unittitle: Mazzini, Joseph to the New York Committee for the Universal Republican AllianceLondon, England

scopecontent.p: After warning about the "divorce between thought and action" that has too often characterized contemporary affairs in which "many pledges have been broken" but expressing his faith that the New York Committee for the Universal Republican Alliance will make good on its promise to help the Universal Republican cause, Giuseppe (here anglicized to "Joseph") Mazzini celebrates the vision of world-wide republicanism, in which what were previously just local movements against depotism would be united in a cooperation binding Europe, the United States, and South America. Strong emphasis is placed on Mazzini's vision of republicanism as the epitome of Christian values: "Ours is a truly Holy Alliance, a highly religious fact," he writes: "the embodiment into a practical reality of the teacings of eigteen centuries of Christianity and of the aspirations of the great good and brave men of all times and countries, all pointing to One God and One Humanity." Mazzini goes on to outline three steps to bring about this universal alliance: the creation of a "continuous uninterrupted organization" with a clear structure; devotion to the Press, including the publication of a series of pamphlets entitled "Universal Republican Alliance"; and the raising of funds in America to support the European Republican Committee.

did.unittitle: Prescott, William H. to Mariotti, L.Boston, MA

scopecontent.p: Prescott congratulates Mariotti on having settled back in his native Italy, recalling Dante's observation about the "hard lot of those who eat the bread of exile." He goes on to thank Mariotti for taking on the project of translating his History of Ferdinand and Isabella into Italian, and provides instructions for Mariotti to acquire a copy from his London bookseller, James Rich, Esq. Prescott has included various "errata and addenda" that he had prepared for the next English edition of the volume, inviting Mariotti to include them in the Italian translation: he worries, though, that certain passages about religion and politics "may require pruning for the meridian of Italy." ("Mariotti" was the adopted name of the Italian literary scholar Antonio Gallenga.)

did.unittitle: Gibson, Th. Milner to Marrioti, L.Hardwick House, Suffolk, England

scopecontent.p: Opens by thanking Mariotti for his previous letter, which helped to stimulate and comfort Gibson in his "loneliness," as he is now living far from his friends. Gibson provides a brief account of his daily life, including family rituals on Sunday: here he favorably remembers "[Giuseppe] Mazzini's Sunday lecture to his prophets," contrasting Mazzini's spirituality to what Gibson deems the unfavorable qualities of the established Church. The bulk of the letter is dedicated to an account of Gibner's being in court recently when several individuals were sentenced to death for committing or being an accessory to murder: he provides a detailed description of the pain of watching one man in particular being sentenced to death: how the man bowed his head, how his wife fainted. Death, Gibson insists, is a terrible thing, especially when it comes suddenly in youth, and when it carries blame, as in the case of criminal execution. Gibson notes that he was "sick at heart" when he left the court room. The letter then concludes with Gibson's plans for coming to town and with light social chatter about one of his and Mariotti's common acquaintances. The letter is written on stationary bearing the name "Arethusa," the name of Gibson's wife. ("Mariotti" was the adopted name of the Italian literary scholar Antonio Gallenga.)

scopecontent.p: Apologizes for not having continued his daily updates of the arrival of French troops in Civitavecchia after his earlier letters of April 24 and April 25 (see bdr710161 and bdr710162), citing lack of developments and the suspension of the post for Rome as causes for the interruption. Remarks the ongoing arrival of French ships of war and notes that, since some troops are arriving in Civitavecchia and marching to Rome while others are marching to Civitavecchia from the direction of Rome, "the intentions of the French are not to be known." Reports rumors about the arrival in Civitavecchia of the Prince Del Carretto in disguise. A postscript to the letter reports upon the passage in nearby waters of the American ship "Princeton," said to be carrying diplomats from Florence to meet the Grand Duke of Tuscany at Gaeta.

scopecontent.p: Regards French projectile attacks on the city of Rome, which have been ongoing for twenty-two days, have damaged even the city's most well-known monuments, and have victimized elderly people, women, and children. After describing the dire situation to Brown, the six signees of this letter present Brown the hope that, as the representative of a great and civil nation and in the interest of humanitarianism, he will come to their aid and help prevent the outbreak of war.

did.unittitle: Carli, Carlo to Brown, NicholasComacchio, Italy

origination.corpname: Consulate of the United States of America in Comacchio

scopecontent.p: Reports the defeat of boats carrying Garibaldi and his men by the Austrian fleet in the waters off the port of Goro. According to Carli, Garibaldi is said to have escaped with his wife, staff, and some soldiers to land between the ports of Magnavacca and Volano: many of these, including Garibaldi and his wife, are said to have set off across the territory disguised as country peasants. Among Garibaldi's disembarked soldiers were Father Ugo Bassi (a Bolognese priest) and a Captain Ringhini, who headed towards Comacchio only to be arrested for not carrying passports: they are now in jail in Comacchio. Carli promises to update Brown as further information becomes available to him.

did.unittitle: Latimer, H.K. to Brown, NicholasBay of Spezzia, Italy

scopecontent.p: Regards the case of Joseph Eismenger, an adolescent Hungarian boy on board Latimer's U.S. Frigate Cumberland. Latimer recounts what he has learned of Joseph: that during the 1848 Hungarian revolution he joined the army with his father—Anton Eismenger—and brother; that his father and brother were killed as prisoners of war; that Joseph escaped to Switzerland and then Italy, where he joined Latimer's ship. Latimer asks Brown to find information about Joseph's uncle, Ferdinand Eismenger, a Hungarian general who is said to have survived and escaped to Rome, or any other surviving relations of the boy, such as possibly an aunt who now lives in a convent in Rome.

did.unittitle: Deposizione di Ceccarini, GaetanoRome, Italy

scopecontent.p: Notarized deposition issued by the Roman Republic testifying to brutalities committed by French soldiers invading Rome. The deponent and several other men fighting to defend the Roman Republic were supposedly thrown out of windows by the French, causing the death of at least two. Accompanied by official English translation of deposition. Name of notary: Giacomo Gagiotti.

did.unittitle: Nicholas Brown's personal congratulations on creation of Roman RepublicRome, Italy

scopecontent.p: Draft, with edits added in pencil between penned lines, of a communication prepared by Nicholas Brown to congratulate the leaders of the Roman Republic on the establishment of a democratically-elected government. Although Brown is not authorized to make any proclamation on behalf of the American government, he wishes to express his "personal satisfaction at this memorable event." Brown goes on to note that it has previously always been a "cardinal principle" of the American government "to acknowledge as supreme any government which a people may choose to institute," since a people have "the fundamental right of subverting or remodelling old forms of rule, or establishing a new order of things." The communication concludes by insisting that because of Americans' love of liberty, the establishment of the Roman Republic will be celebrated across America long before diplomats have time to speak officially on the issue. Both pages of the document contain handwritten pencil notes on the reverse: one reads, "To Roman Govt"; the other notes that "a copy of this was sent in my name to Mr. Buchanan, Sec of State."

did.unittitle: Brown, Nicholas to Rusconi, CarloRome, Italy

scopecontent.p: Assures Rusconi, the foreign affairs minister of the Roman Republic, that the government of the United States will recognize the Roman Republic at the nearest opportune moment. Brown goes on to express his enthusiasm for the Roman Republic, praising in particular the calm that its government has been able to maintain despite turbulent circumstances and speaking of a new "modern Rome" that follows in the legacy of the great men of its storied past. Contains handwritten edits, some in English.

did.unittitle: Brown, Nicholas to Monsieur AmbassadeurRome, Italy

scopecontent.p: Draft of a letter regarding the petition signed by Brown and other consuls in Rome and sent to General Charles Oudinot to end the bombardment of the city by French troops. Brown references newspaper coverage of the affair, including a letter to Oudinot published by Karl von Kolb, Consul of Württemburg. Brown protests the ambassador's response to the bombardment and goes on to cite his reasons for signing the petition, including the suffering of innocent victims and the destruction of public property.

did.unittitle: Some drunken French soldiers at the American consulateRome, Italy

scopecontent.p: Description of an occurence involving "some drunken French soldiers" outside the house of the American consul in Rome. After the French soldiers were prevented from forcing their way into the house in pursuit of individuals whom they perceived to be laughing at them, they arrested several Roman soldiers. The American consul Nicholas Brown informed the French General Oudinot of the situation, who immediately ordered the release of the seized men: an apology was made.
